conclusion: The ideal gas law is given by PV = nRT.

At state A: P_A = p_0, T_A = T_0, and V_A = V_0. AB is parallel to the V-axis, pressure remains constant at p_0 from A to B. BC passes through the origin, indicating V and T are directly proportional.
At state B, pressure is p_0 and volume is 2V_0.
Using the ideal gas law at A: p_0 V_0 = nRT_0.
Using the ideal gas law at B: p_0 (2V_0) = nRT_B.
Solving for T_B: 2p_0 V_0 = nRT_B implies T_B = 2T_0.
At state C, V is proportional to T. Volume is V_0 and temperature is T_C.
Using proportionality: V_C/T_C = V_B/T_B. Substituting values gives T_C = T_0.
The temperature at state C is T_0.
